stem: A postpartum patient is being discharged home. Drag and drop the following instructions into the correct categories to ensure patient safety and understanding.

solution.followUp: Attend your scheduled postpartum check-up in 6 weeks.
solution.medication: Take Ibuprofen 200mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain.
solution.mentalHealth: Contact your provider if you experience persistent sadness or anxiety.
solution.warningSigns: Report increased bleeding or foul-smelling discharge to your healthcare provider.
solution.infantFeeding: Breastfeed every 2-3 hours or formula feed every 3-4 hours as directed.
solution.postpartumCare: Cleanse the perineal area with warm water after each void.

rationale.correct: Adhering to medication schedules, scheduling follow-up appointments, and understanding warning signs promotes a safe recovery. Correct perineal care prevents infection and promotes healing. Proper infant feeding ensures adequate nutrition and bonding. Mental health considerations are vital for postpartum well-being.

mnemonic.name: POST BIRTH
mnemonic.description: Pain in chest, Obstructed breathing/SOB, Seizures, Thoughts of harming self or baby; Bleeding (soaking pad in an hour), Incision not healing, Red or swollen leg, Temperature >100.4F, Headache that doesn't get better

rationale.incorrect: Ignoring warning signs, neglecting perineal care, or inconsistent infant feeding practices can lead to complications. Delaying follow-up appointments can hinder early detection of potential problems. Dismissing mental health needs can negatively impact the mother's well-being and infant care.

questionTrap.commonMistake: Patients often underestimate the importance of self-care and follow-up appointments.
questionTrap.reasonForMistake: Lack of understanding or prioritization of their own health needs in the context of caring for a newborn.

clinicalPearls: Postpartum education is crucial for a successful transition home.
Early recognition of complications can prevent serious health issues.
A supportive environment is essential for the mother's physical and emotional well-being.

itemContext.sbar: Patient is stable for discharge.  She delivered vaginally two days ago.  Fundus is firm and at the umbilicus. Lochia is rubra, moderate amount.  Perineum is intact. Patient reports mild discomfort.  Infant is breastfeeding well.  Patient has expressed some anxiety about going home.

possibleResponses: Report increased bleeding or foul-smelling discharge to your healthcare provider.
Attend your scheduled postpartum check-up in 6 weeks.
Take Ibuprofen 200mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain.
Cleanse the perineal area with warm water after each void.
Breastfeed every 2-3 hours or formula feed every 3-4 hours as directed.
Contact your provider if you experience persistent sadness or anxiety.
